lines.text:
[watching a riot on TV]
What do you expect if you keep taking people's jobs away?
Got nothing to do with it.
What do you mean?
They don't want jobs. At least not the kind they're qualified to do. So even if we did manage to open all those steel mills and dog biscuit factories, we wouldn't get them to sign on.
Are you saying they don't want to work?
Oh, I dare say they wouldn't mind being president of IBM or a TV star. Or John McEnroe.

[on married life]
Well, we gave each other total freedom and we hated each other for taking total advantage of it.
You don't even seem to be angry.
I can't afford to get angry. If I ever let myself get angry I could do some real damage.
I decided they really piss me off, women.
What do you mean?
What? All this relating. Relationships. Inter-relating.
That's what they're good at.

Oh, don't get me wrong, I always endorsed all that. I used to argue Feminism against women. I was such a good boy, you know. I even joined the men's group once. God, that was really depressing. Endless whingeing. It's not like the women's group, they enjoy themselves. They used to meet at our flat. I used to hear them haranging one another or roaring with laughter while I was making the bloody tea. I really envied them. I knew at the time they were right to be angry. They were absolutely justified, never disputed that for a moment. All the same, they really pissed me off.
Couldn't they come up with some sort of compromise?
Compromise? She's taking him to Australia. What sort of compromise do you suggest, Singapore?
So you had absolutely no idea your wife was subject to these tendencies?
None whatsoever.
Good. And how did you find out?
My son told me.
Oh, excellent. What did he say?
She shares a bed with this women.
Who is a known Lesbian?
Yes. She got married once.
Excuse me?
To another women. Read something about it somewhere. Gay News. Don't know if she's had a divorce.
Well, this is most promising. And where has your wife taken the boy?
Brixton.
Oh, wonderful.
Quick smash and grab in the County Court. We can get away with it, don't you think, Leonard?
A bit of a long shot, isn't it? I would have thought we'd stand a better chance with a magistrate.
But not much fun, though. Also a bit hit and miss. What we need is the right judge.
Now, this is your affidavit, Mr Miles. It sets out your reason for applying for care and control.
Should be alright. Bound to be, really. Can always rely on Kirby Smith for a genuinely reactionary decision.
When shall we three meet again? Or four.
It's very depressing round here. You know it all all?
Yes. I've lived here for years.
Ah, South London. A flavour all of its own.
[Dancing]
Wading through the muck and mire. Hello, muck. Higher mire!
The trick was to get the same judge sit to preside over the final hearing. Same judge, same verdict. That's the beauty of the system.

[on relationships]
When I was at university you had to fight all the way. It was all about negotiated settlements.
Tell me something. Just as a matter of interest. Have you had anything similar in your own life?
What do you mean?
Separation. Divorce. A friend losing a child?
Yeah, I suppose so.
Thought as much. It's always the way. The crony in the background vicariously working out his anger, or her. It's much more commonly a women.
Is it?
Anyway. Hope you're feeling better now.
Tell me something. Does the name shitbum mean anything to you?
Well, we certainly jerked her lead.
Why did you have to say that?
I wouldn't have. But it's true.
